column1: Rabbit Holes: Why Exploring the Weird Limits of Google Maps Is the Best Way to Kill Time
column8: Rabbit Holes: Why a 1950s Motivational Video Is the Best Form of Procrastination Rabbit Holes is a recurring series in which writers pay homage to the diversity and ingenuity of the ways we procrastinate now. To pitch your personal rabbit hole, email . Lakshmi Mudragada did not have a good time on Sea Cow Island. Sure, the potato-shaped land mass in the middle of the Indian Ocean doesnâ€™t have any amenities, but the generic tropical beach picture on Google Maps looks nice enough. What went wrong? The one-star review on Google isnâ€™t accompanied by text, so perhaps the story behind it will always be a mystery. But trying to untangle the mysteries behind various aspects of Google Maps is my preferred way to kill time. For example, how did Lakshmi get out to SCI in the first place? Or did they even really go there at all? When you try to get directions to the remote British territory from Brooklyn, for instance, it breaks the program. Rather than direct you to a regional airport in Madagascar or somewhere else â€œnearby,â€ it just zooms out so far that it shows a picture of Earth situated in the black expanse of outer space. I find this only slightly more intriguing than terrifying. Even though I spend all day on the internet, my world feels very small sometimes. The lives of people in areas like Palau or the Marshall Islands arenâ€™t usually portrayed on TV or film. But Google Maps reviewers provide clues from which I can make up stories about these places on the other side of the earth, and sometimes they offer pictures that help fill in a coherent vision of them. Itâ€™s like a choose-your-own-adventure travel guide where everything is annotated in the most bizarre way possibleâ€”a â€œ Bandersnatch â€ where you can play for as long or as little as you like and donâ€™t have to worry about reaching any sort of satisfying narrative conclusion. When the story broke about the missionary who was killed trying to contact the last pre-Neolithic society on earth off the coast of the Andaman and Nicobar Islands this past November, I understood his curiosity, if not his confidence. Iâ€™d already pored over the Bay of Bengal and its archipelago from the comfort of my desk chair, and Iâ€™d seen the offerings at a roadside restaurant off National Highway 4 that takes you from the coastal point of Mayabunder to the capital of Port Blair. Iâ€™d also noticed that Google did not have the slightest data point available for the last place the missionary ever tried to set foot, beyond the fact that it existed. My procrastination habit isnâ€™t just limited to the last blank spots on the Google map either; more familiar places work just as well. A co-worker recently told me that his sister had moved to someplace in my home state of Florida; he had to go and Google the name, even though heâ€™d just been there. It turns out the forgettable town was called Freeport, and upon learning this, my immediate instinct was to look it up. Itâ€™s a suburb and therefore shaped like a plate of spaghetti, with no obvious Main Street or place to begin a journey. Searching for a clue of where to start, I scrolled through the placeâ€™s few commercial offerings, which is how I ended up on the page for Paul Lee Tattoo. The proprietorâ€™s works include your typical yin-yangs and tribal patterns, sure, but photos from the shop also include a still-bleeding back freshly inked with a gator depicted busting through a wall like a reptilian version of the Kool-Aid Man. After completing this digital trek, I was pleased to report back to my co-worker with sympathies and a pointed recommendation of where his sister should never get a tattoo. Looking at your own hometown through the lens of Google Maps can also be enlightening. After all, the reviews represent a collection of what people there deem important or indicative ofâ€”something, although of what is up to you. In the case of Lake Mary, Florida, you get front-on shots of cookie-cutter houses and architecturally lacking commercial properties, a Chick-fil-A decorated for Christmas, a bad-looking steak at a sports bar, empty parking lots, and a Confederate flag in a display case. Thatâ€™s a relatively accurate portrait, though not one I would have ever put together myself. I wonder how it would read to an outsider, though, or to someone as unfamiliar with the American South as I am with an app-breaking destination called Tristan da Cunha ? All I have to go on there are cryptic yet poetic messages that give me no idea of what a lived experience is actually like in the most remote yet inhabited archipelago on earth. Oddly: â€œThe people â€¦ drift off walking sideways mid conversation.â€ Ominously: â€œThe return to the past is the real future.â€ Or, more simply: â€œToo far.â€

column1: William Barr rigged Donald Trumpâ€™s acquittal.
column8:
How Are We Supposed to Understand Brett Kavanaugh Now? Five weeks ago, special counsel Robert Mueller gave Attorney General William Barr a 448-page report on the Russia investigation. The report documented multiple attempts by President Donald Trump to manipulate, disrupt, and terminate the investigation. But two days after receiving the report, Barr announced that the evidence was insufficient to charge Trump with obstruction of justice. How did Barr reach that conclusion? On Wednesday, we got the answer: He devised legal standards that make it impossible to convict a president of obstruction. At Wednesdayâ€™s hearing before the Senate Judiciary Committee , Barr testified not as the nationâ€™s chief law enforcement officer but as a defense attorney for the president. When Sen. Amy Klobuchar of Minnesota asked Barr about Trumpâ€™s attempts to manipulate witnesses, the attorney general rebutted her by presenting what, in his opinion, â€œthe presidentâ€™s lawyers would say.â€ Barr dismissed Muellerâ€™s efforts to get an interview with Trumpâ€”Mueller â€œnever sought it. â€¦ Well, he never pushed it,â€ the attorney general liedâ€”and he complained that Muellerâ€™s analysis of the presidentâ€™s obstructive conduct â€œpermits a lot of selectivity on the part of the prosecutors.â€ In place of Muellerâ€™s analysis, Barr laid down four rules that guaranteed Trump would escape prosecution. 1. A presidentâ€™s efforts to terminate an investigation of himself are presumptively innocent. Under U.S. law, anyone accused of a crime is presumed innocent. But Barr clings to this presumption even after the president has attempted, on multiple occasions, to abort an inquiry into his own alleged misconduct. Barr told the committee that Trumpâ€™s presidential ordersâ€”including the firing of thenâ€“FBI Director James Comey in May 2017 and the attempted firing of Mueller a month laterâ€”were â€œauthorized by the Constitutionâ€ and therefore â€œfacially innocent.â€ 2. No amount of evidence can disprove a presidentâ€™s post hoc account of his motives. Mueller presented copious evidence that Trump, having decided to fire Comey because of the Russia investigation, seized on a completely different rationaleâ€”outlined in a memo by Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosensteinâ€”as a pretext for the firing. But at Wednesdayâ€™s hearing, when Sen. John Cornyn of Texas asked Barr whether Trump â€œwas relying, at least in part,â€ on Rosensteinâ€™s critique, the attorney general assured Cornyn, â€œThatâ€™s right.â€ Mueller also documented conversations in which thenâ€“White House counsel Don McGahn and former New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie, an ex-prosecutor, explained to Trump that there were no grounds to fire Mueller based on putative conflicts of interest. But at the hearing, Barr insisted that Trumpâ€™s subsequent efforts to oust Mueller might have been based not on fear of the Russia investigation but on the alleged conflicts of interest. Barr defended the presidentâ€™s preposterous lie about his attempt, through McGahn, to fire Mueller. In June 2017, Trumpâ€™s chief of staff, Reince Priebus, and Trumpâ€™s chief strategist, Steve Bannon, said Trump was strongly considering firing Mueller. A few days later, Trump called McGahn twice at home and told him to get rid of the special counsel. According to McGahn, Trump repeatedly pressed him to contact Rosensteinâ€”â€œCall me back when you do it,â€ the president told McGahnâ€”and oust the special counsel because â€œMueller has to go.â€ But at Wednesdayâ€™s hearing, Barr stood up for Trumpâ€™s version of the episode. â€œWhat he meant,â€ said Barr, paraphrasing Trumpâ€™s account, â€œwas that the conflict of interest should be raised with Rosenstein, but the decision should be left with Rosenstein.â€ Barr was equally generous in his defense of Trumpâ€™s signals to witnesses. Klobuchar asked the attorney general about public comments in which Trump had warned two witnesses in the investigation, Michael Cohen and Paul Manafort, not to â€œflip.â€ Barr replied that Trump could easily defend those comments. â€œBy flipping, he meant succumbing to pressure in unrelated cases to lieâ€ against the president, Barr suggested. Thatâ€™s an odd claim to make about Manafortâ€”who was found to have lied to prosecutors while protecting Trump â€”or Cohen, whose testimony against Trump was corroborated by checks and audio recordings . 3. If a president thinks any part of an allegation is false, he can lawfully obstruct an investigation of that allegation. On Jan. 25, 2018, the New York Times reported Trumpâ€™s attempt, through McGahn, to fire Mueller in June 2017. In the week after the Times story appeared, Trump repeatedly pressed McGahn to deny the story. McGahn refused, saying the article was true. Trump rebuked McGahn for taking notes, demanded that he deny the story in writing â€œfor our records,â€ and threatened to fire him if he didnâ€™t recant. Mueller documented this episode through White House records and multiple witnesses. But at Wednesdayâ€™s hearing, Barr insisted that Trumpâ€™s intent was innocent because one word in the Times article was debatable. â€œThe New York Times story said flat-out that the president directed the firing of Mueller,â€ said Barr. He noted that Trump later denied having used the word â€œfireâ€ in his calls to McGahn. Therefore, said Barr, it was possible that â€œthe president truly felt that the Times article was inaccurateâ€ and, in ordering his White House counsel to recant, didnâ€™t think â€œhe was instructing McGahn to say something false.â€ 4. If a president thinks any part of an investigation is unfounded, he can lawfully shut it down. Barr told Sen. Patrick Leahy of Vermont that if a legal proceeding was â€œbased on false allegations, the president does not have to sit there, constitutionally, and allow it to run its course. The president could terminate that proceeding, and it would not be a corrupt intent, because he was being falsely accused.â€ The attorney general made the same argument to Sen. Dianne Feinstein of California, contending that a â€œfalsely accusedâ€ president could fire a special counsel without corrupt intent. Barr didnâ€™t confine this argument to meritless inquiries. He applied it to investigations that involved any false allegations. He specifically said it was a valid basis for terminating the Russia investigation since the president â€œwas being falsely accused.â€ â€œTwo years of his administration have been dominated by allegations that have now been proven false,â€ Barr told the committee. In defiance of Muellerâ€™s report , he claimed that Trump â€œdid nothing wrongâ€ and that suspicions of collusion between Russia and Trumpâ€™s campaign were â€œwithout a basis.â€ Together, Barrâ€™s four rules make an obstruction of justice case impossible. The president could stand in the middle of Fifth Avenue, fire the FBI director, fire a special counsel, threaten witnesses, and instruct subordinates to lie, and he wouldnâ€™t lose the support of his attorney general. Thatâ€™s why Trump hired Barr in the first place. And thatâ€™s why Muellerâ€™s investigation shouldnâ€™t end with Barrâ€™s refusal to prosecute the president. We canâ€™t let a lawyer acquit his own client. Support our journalism

column1: Ben Sasse, Barr hearing: Explains problem with legal Trump-Russia links.
column8:
Oglala Sioux Tribe Tells South Dakota Governor That She Is â€œNot Welcomeâ€ on Reservation In the first volume of his report to the attorney general about Donald Trumpâ€™s â€œlinksâ€ to Russia, special counsel Robert Mueller wrote that the evidence his team had gathered â€œdid not establish that members of the Trump Campaign conspired or coordinated with the Russian government in its election interference activities.â€ Not surprisingly, Trump interpreted this conclusion as a â€œcomplete and total exoneration,â€ while Attorney General William Barr described it as a conclusion that â€œno collusionâ€ took place in 2016. Thatâ€™s not quite what the Mueller report says, though. For one, it notes that it does not address the issue of â€œcollusionâ€ because the word collusion doesnâ€™t have a specific legal meaning. For another, it says that some of the witnesses investigators spoke to provided â€œinformation that was false or incomplete,â€ â€œdeleted relevant communications,â€ or â€œcommunicated during the relevant period using applications that feature encryptionâ€â€”limitations that the special counsel says may have prevented its office from gathering information that â€œwould shed additional light on (or cast in a new light) the events described in the report.â€ And finally, the report does conclude, even if it stops short of recommending criminal conspiracy charges, that the Trump campaign was â€œreceptiveâ€ to some offers of Russian assistance and â€œexpected it would benefit electorally from information stolen and released through Russian efforts.â€ According to Mueller, Russia in turn â€œperceived it would benefit from a Trump presidency.â€ Which, as Nebraska Republican Sen. Ben Sasse and Delaware Democratic Sen. Chris Coons pointed out in their questions to Barr during Wednesdayâ€™s Senate Judiciary Committee hearing, is not necessarily a great state of affairs. Sasse is the kind of Republican who tends to get exasperated at Trump for constantly doing things that are reckless and destructive. But he also represents MAGA-friendly red-state constituents , so his remarks werenâ€™t phrased in a confrontational gotcha format. They nonetheless laid out concisely why itâ€™s concerning that Trump et al.â€™s attitude toward Russian influence has not, as of yet, been disincentivized. Get The Angle in Your Inbox

Manafort served as Trumpâ€™s campaign chairman on an ostensibly â€œvolunteerâ€ basis, but, per Muellerâ€™s report, sought to exploit the high-profile position financially. One of the ways he appears to have done so, according to Mueller, was by offering Russian billionaire Oleg Deripaskaâ€”a close ally of Vladimir Putinâ€™s who had previously employed Manafort for consulting workâ€”access to the campaign. As Sasse put it:
Paul Manafort is hired by Deripaska for things related to the Ukraine. â€¦ He is on the payroll of a Russian oligarch that has interests completely disaligned with the American people. He is on his payroll. Is it permissible for [an American campaign official] to be paid by someone who is basically an enemy of the United States? Manafort was charged with a number of crimes that Mueller uncovered, but none were directly related to 2016 activities involving Deripaska. The special counsel also chose not to prosecute exâ€“National Security Adviser Michael Flynn, who, like Manafort, had recent financial ties to Russia and demonstrated a willingness to advance Russian interests while working for Trump. Ostensibly, Mueller made this decision because neither Manafort nor Flynn were in touch with the specific Russian operatives who carried out cyberattacks against Democrats; likewise, neither individual appears to have been caught giving a tangible indication that their interest in Russia-friendly policies was a reward for Russiaâ€™s sabotage of Clinton. As Sasse pointed out, though, this would suggest that it would be OK with the Department of Justice for a foreign country like Russia or China to cultivate influence by systematically putting as many American campaign operatives as possible on retainer in the hopes that theyâ€™d end up, like Manafort, as influential â€œvolunteersâ€ on U.S. campaigns:
Could they come in and build a database of all campaign operatives in the U.S.? And just decide to hire all of them and say, why donâ€™t you volunteer for this campaign and you volunteer for that campaign? Could we have campaign chairmen and women running around the U.S. paid for by foreign entities, choosing to volunteer on campaigns, going forward? Is that legal? And later:
If the Chinese government decides to start hacking into 2020 campaigns, I would hope there is clarity from the Department of Justice about whether or not Democratic presidential campaigns and whether the Trump re-election campaign are allowed to say, â€œwe are interested in this hacked material.â€ Barr didnâ€™t have much of a response for Sasse, calling the subject â€œa slippery areaâ€ and saying that whether any of the hypothetical behavior Sasse described would be criminal â€œdepends on the specific circumstances.â€ The issue was framed even more pithily by Delawareâ€™s Coons, who targeted Barr with a question based on the June 9, 2016, Trump Tower meeting attended by three top Trump advisers and several Russians. The Russians had high-level government and intelligence connections and had conveyed through an intermediary that they were interested in providing the Trump campaign incriminating material about Clinton in the context of â€œRussia and its governmentâ€™s support for Mr. Trump.â€ No one on the Trump campaign was charged for the incident; Muellerâ€™s report concludes that prosecuting them for accepting illegal foreign campaign support would have been difficult because of ambiguity over whether they â€œhad general knowledge that their conduct was unlawfulâ€ and whether incriminating information legally constitutes â€œa thing of valueâ€ as the relevant statute requires. Coonsâ€™ question put Barr on the spot as to whether this is supposed to mean the meeting was A-OK.
COONS: Going forward, what if a foreign adversaryâ€”letâ€™s now say North Koreaâ€”offers a presidential candidate dirt on a competitor in 2020? Do you agree with me the campaign should immediately contact the FBI?
BARR: [Long pause] If a foreign government?
COONS: If a foreign intelligence service, a representative of a foreign governmentâ€”
BARR: Yes. Yes.
COONS: â€”says, â€œWe have dirt on your opponent,â€ should they say â€œ I love it , letâ€™s meet,â€ or should they contact the FBI?
BARR: If a foreign intelligence service does, yes. So, Barrâ€™s answer appears to be that campaigns should worry about being approached by well-connected foreigners who want to trade incriminating information for changes to money-laundering laws only if those foreigners are wearing, letâ€™s say, T-shirts and novelty baseball caps that say WE ARE FOREIGN SPIES. Itâ€™s an interesting position for the U.S.â€™s top law enforcement officer to take, but thatâ€™s where we are now.

column1: History of the California roll and its possible inventor, Hidekazu Tojo.
column8:
The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Netflix, HBO, Amazon Prime, and Hulu in May Hidekazu Tojo came to Vancouver from Osaka, Japan in 1971. Young, ambitious, and classically trained in sushi arts, he was a perfect match for Shigeru Hirai, who was looking for a young chef to work with. Hirai offered Tojo a two-year contract at his small sushi restaurant, Maneki, in Vancouverâ€™s Japantown. There werenâ€™t many Japanese restaurants in Vancouver at the time, and even fewer still that served raw fish. Japanese diners raved about Tojoâ€™s sushi. The local Canadians, on the other hand, only favored the cooked dishes. â€œI watched them eat spinach salad, tempura, and teriyaki chicken very, very quickly,â€ Tojo tells me over hot tea at his current restaurant, Tojoâ€™s. â€œBut the sushi they refused before they tasted. They didnâ€™t eat raw crab and tuna â€¦ raw they didnâ€™t eat.â€ Given the popularity and ubiquity of sushi today, itâ€™s hard to imagine a time when we werenâ€™t eating raw fish, but such was the case in 1970s North America. For Tojo, a trained sushi chef, watching his customers forgo his piÃ¨ce de rÃ©sistance, day in and day out, motivated him to make his sushi better.
Tojo on a trip to Alberta (Banff, Jasper, Calgary, Edmonton). Rocky Mountains, c. 1972 or 1973.
Momoko, Tojoâ€™s Daughter But first, he needed to figure out why they didnâ€™t want to try it in the first place. Eventually, Tojo moved outside of the familiarity of Japantown and became the head chef at a new spot, Jinya, on the highly trafficked and diverse West Broadway. He struck up a relationship with one of his regulars, a young flight attendant named Mami Yamaguchi, at the now-defunct CPA Airlines. Unlike most of the local Canadians who came to eat at Tojoâ€™s restaurant, Mami was Japanese herself; she spoke multiple languages and didnâ€™t shy away from trying Tojoâ€™s sushi, which quickly endeared her to Tojo. She became, in a sense, his cultural translator, taking him to the popular French restaurants at the time, like William Tell, where Tojo noticed Canadians did in fact enjoy seafood, especially local Dungeness crabâ€”when it was boiled. With Mamiâ€™s guidance, Tojo started to explore the local fish markets in pursuit of his most pressing question, â€œWhy donâ€™t Canadians like raw fish?â€ Tojo wandered the seafood aisles of Safeway and the local market on Granville Island to see where Canadians were shopping for fish. In contrast to the Japanese suppliers he was buying from, the Canadian markets, it turned out, served their fish with less presentation. â€œNo decoration, very bad smell. Fish smell,â€ Tojo recounted. â€œIn my training when you go to the market, seafood smells just like watermelon, fresh watermelon, or cucumber smell. Big difference. Over there, Safeway? Ah! Stinky! Thatâ€™s why.â€ Suddenly the driving question to Tojoâ€™s sushi conundrum had an answer: smelly fish. Tojo decided to create a sushi that Canadians would like, one that didnâ€™t require the use of the local supply. It wasnâ€™t so much a concession as a vestige of his training in Osaka, where he was known for his omakase creations, i.e. serving the customersâ€™ needs with what was fresh and available. Omakase in Japanese loosely translates to â€œIâ€™ll leave it up to you.â€ Itâ€™s more than just a menu; itâ€™s a ritual built on the ever-changing ingredients in the chefâ€™s kitchen, while still considering the desires of the customer. Many omakase chefs donâ€™t have a predetermined menu in mind; rather, they build the menu as it unfolds, relying on a sense of what works and what doesnâ€™t for each individual customer. It necessitates, in other words, a certain type of trust between the customer and the chef. What made Tojoâ€™s style of omakase different was that he didnâ€™t feel bound by his locale, North America. Take, for instance, his favorite dish unagi , or barbecued eel, which simply wasnâ€™t available as an ingredient in Vancouver. In order to offer it as a menu item, he instead used the skin of a fish that came to Canada in droves, salmon, seasoning it with the classic sauce used on traditional unagi. This was, in effect, the way Tojoâ€™s California roll was born: by mixing what was available and accessible to him, with what people in his restaurant actually wanted to eat. Nothing more or less elaborate than that. Tojo doesnâ€™t remember the exact day or circumstance that led to the roll. He does, however, remember many customers complaining about eating seaweed. So one day, he replaced the raw fish with avocado and boiled local crab, inspired by what he saw at William Tell. Then, he hid the nori behind a veil of rice by rolling the sushi inside out. Finally, to really make the roll sing, he added a little mayonnaise. â€œWe were born very poor,â€ he said. â€œThat time after the war, no food. We put mayonnaise and greens from the garden. That is kind of like Western food, little bit fancy. Before they put only soy sauce. But when we discovered mayonnaise, we put in lettuce, tomato, cucumberâ€”put mayo, I love it!â€ To be clear, the California roll on the menu at Tojoâ€™s restaurant is called the Tojo Maki, not the California roll. Tojo had never even been to California at that point in time (a detail he has impressed on me several times). While the name â€œTojo Makiâ€ enjoys significantly less notoriety than â€œCalifornia roll,â€ Tojo insists that he was the first to come up with it. Asked why I should believe his version of the California rollâ€™s origin story, he replied simply, â€œIn Japan you have pride. Good chef never copies. Never.â€ The competing theory is that the California roll was, in fact, invented in Californiaâ€™s Little Tokyo in the 1970s. According to this version of events, a man named Kanai Noritoshi, who owned a Japanese food import company called Mutual Trading Company, started what was considered the first sushi counter, Kawafuku, and it was there that he invented the â€œCaliforniaâ€ maki. Kawafukuâ€™s head chef, Ichiro Mashita, also claimed credit after starting his own restaurant, Tokyo Kaikan. As for Tojoâ€™s attempts at solidifying his place in California roll history, he did try to trademark his roll in the early â€˜90s, after the fact. For this he called on his lawyer, Barry Joe, who has been working with Tojo for 40 years. Unfortunately, for the progenitors of all things wacky maki, trademarking a recipe is extremely difficult to enforce, and extremely costly, at close to several thousand dollars a year for a patent on something like the Tojo Maki. For the rest of us, the who of who can legitimately claim credit for the California roll feels besides the point. The idea that people want to claim credit for its invention at all is a testament to its ubiquity, and to its ultimate commercial success. The California rollâ€™s rise didnâ€™t occur without its critics, like chef Hiroko Shimbo, author of The Sushi Experience . â€œThe California roll is not Japanese sushi because it was created for the convenience of American diners,â€ she said. â€œWe call it â€˜sushi,â€™ but thatâ€™s another dish.â€ I asked Shimbo whether she thought it was authentic. â€œNo,â€ she explained. â€œWhy is it not authentic is simply the nori, when we make rolls in Japan, is always outside. And of course there is a reason nori is on the outside: to keep the sushi rice moist and juicy (and the nori gets a little chewy), and thatâ€™s how rolls are made in Japan.â€ As Shimbo speaks, I canâ€™t help but wonder: Is authenticity not chimerical? Cross-cultural remakes of culinary classics date back to globalization itself. The English soup mulligatawny originated from the Indian dish molo tunny; L.A. galbi came from Korean immigrants in California who made use of a cheaper cut newly available to them; and even tempura exists thanks to the Portuguese (although now it seems so steeped in authentic Japanese tradition that considering it anything else seems preposterous). â€œWhenever some new dish comes to oneâ€™s country from another country, that food is always transformed into a slightly different form in order to appeal to the people in that new country,â€ Shimbo explained. â€œIn Japan they like soft-textured bagels, so a few companies came up with a soft bagel, kind of a fluffy bagel, and thatâ€™s â€˜bagelâ€™ to the Japanese. And here in America no one can accept that soft bagel.â€ Maybe thatâ€™s what gave the California roll its staying power. Japanese sushi made a small adjustment: a piece of cooked fish in place of raw, a bit of extra sauce and some nori hidden from view. But what is authentic sushi? Even if itâ€™s created for Americans, is it not still sushi? Maybe not what Shimbo grew up associating with sushi, but sushi nonethelessâ€”without which some of Tojoâ€™s most valued regulars may not have come back for a second or third taste. But what sushi needs in order to be authentic, Shimbo continued, is â€œrespect of each flavor in each ingredient. When we cook something, we donâ€™t add spices or something to mask. Using oil masks the flavor of ingredients, so the chefs or cooks, whenever they make some dish, try to use a method to keep the true flavor of the ingredients at the end of the preparation. So that when you eat chicken you enjoy the flavor of the chicken, not the sauce.â€ Some would say that the California roll, at least a good one, does just that. The balanced combination of ingredients, the subtleties of the riceâ€™s temperature, the freshness of the nori, the perfect amount of mayoâ€”all of these are what make a California roll sing. According to Shimboâ€™s definition, then, maybe there is a version of the California roll thatâ€™s â€œauthenticâ€ and another thatâ€™s not.
Tojo at Jinya, holding a takeout order for restaurant regular, Paul Belserene.
Momoko, Tojoâ€™s Daughter Tojoâ€™s creative approach to omakase has led to many other types of adaptations, like the Golden Roll, which does away with nori by wrapping sushi fillings in a thin egg crepe. Or his take on tuna sashimi, which comes pre-marinated to avoid the chance of a customer getting the wrong balance of fish to wasabi to soy. Visible in all of Tojoâ€™s menu items is this well-worn habit of â€œtrickingâ€ his customers into trying more and more of his sushiâ€”what may appear to be sushi gimmicks, but which clearly are clever maneuvers to appeal to the palette heâ€™s catering to. One of Tojoâ€™s most valued regulars, Paul Belserene, couldnâ€™t stomach uni until he tried Tojoâ€™s preparation of it, which now has him hooked. column1: Mueller canâ€™t get away with silence anymore.
column8:
Mueller Spent Years Collecting Evidence. Barr Is Pretending Itâ€™s Not There. For almost all of the story of To Kill a Mockingbird, Boo Radley is nothing more than a metaphor. Heâ€™s a mysterious, shadowy figure who can be pressed into service to symbolize any number of literary tropes, but despite the importuning of primary characters who only want Boo to come out of his house, he only does so when heâ€™s ready, and when itâ€™s necessary. Robert Mueller has been, for more than two years, a metaphor. Heâ€™s been the guy whose firing would have signified the pick-up-a-brick moment for millions of Americans , heâ€™s been the caped superhero coming to save us all, and heâ€™s also been the shadowy Clark Kent, toiling away in dorky obscurity, refusing to engage with whatever it is that corrupts even well-meaning public servants who must interact with Donald Trump. For two years, Mueller has defied all public longings and expectations and demands, instead allowing his indictments, his report, and his words on paper to speak for themselves. But like Boo Radley, itâ€™s now time for Robert Mueller to come out. If Attorney General William Barrâ€™s testimony before the Senate Judiciary Committee on Wednesday demonstrated anything, it was that a deep rupture has yawned open between these two old friends and Washington lifers. It wasnâ€™t just that Barr denigrated Mueller as a â€œpolitical appointeeâ€ or dismissed his March 27 letter as â€œ snitty ,â€ and thus clearly the work of underlings. It wasnâ€™t just that Barr implied that Mueller was either too timid or too incompetent to come to a conclusion on the question of whether Donald Trump had obstructed justice. And it wasnâ€™t just that Barr suggested that since the entire Mueller probe had been proven to be â€œbased on false accusations,â€ it was illegitimate, which certainly suggests that Mueller devoted two long years to aâ€”you guessed itâ€”witch hunt. Presumably, from now on, if the president decides any legal investigation is â€œbased on false accusations,â€ he can just go ahead and impede it , a framing that makes a hash of everything Mueller sought to do. When pressed Wednesday on Muellerâ€™s bona fides, Barr snapped that â€œBob Mueller is the equivalent of a U.S. Attorney. â€¦ His work concluded when he sent his report to the attorney general. At that point, it was my baby.â€ This is not how you talk about a colleague you respect. This studied restraint rested on Muellerâ€™s unwavering assumption that if he trusted the fact-finding process of the investigation and the machinery of the Justice Department, he might come out the other side intact. But itâ€™s not just that. At the most basic level, Barr has distorted Muellerâ€™s actual work product, including his polite and confidential and lawyerly letter asking (twice) that Barr correct his inaccurate summary of Muellerâ€™s careful report. Itâ€™s a letter that Wiredâ€™s Garrett Graff, who wrote a book about Mueller, described thusly : â€œIâ€™ve read just about every word Bob Mueller has ever said publicly or published. Heâ€™s written precisely one letter like the angry one he sent to Barr: It excoriated Scotland for letting the Pan Am 103 bomber out of prison.â€ With the rollout of the report and Wednesdayâ€™s charged testimony, Barr betrayed Mueller the institutionalist not once but twice, first by warping years of his teamâ€™s painstaking investigative work in order to control the media narrative, and then by denigrating Muellerâ€™s March 27 letter as the work of a â€œsnittyâ€ staffer, as opposed to a sober and deliberate bit of caution from the special counsel quietly asking that his work not be appropriated for political ends. Mueller, a lifelong Republican, has triedâ€”probably harder than any public figure in the Trump ambitâ€”to avoid doing anything that would draw him into the tractor beam of bullying, name-calling, and soapy melodrama that are the final resting place for anyone who involves himself with this president. Where lesser men have attempted to split the difference, compromise at the margins, and to persuade themselves that they were still doing noble work despite allowing Donald Trump to use and exploit them, Mueller simply never engaged, even when the president was attacking him by name. It was an elegant dance, along the invisible seam of public and private, institutionalism and self-protection. This studied restraint rested on Muellerâ€™s unwavering assumption that if he trusted the fact-finding process of the investigation and the machinery of the Justice Department , he might come out the other side intact. Well, any hope that Barr the institutionalist or Barr the defender of the Justice Department or Barr the believer in truth-seeking processes was going to help Robert Mueller thread this impossibly small needle was vaporized conclusively this week , and now, as my colleague Mark Joseph Stern argues, Robert Mueller is going to have to talk . Efforts to speak through his filings have proved futile in the hands of someone willing to twist and compromise Muellerâ€™s own words until they mean the very opposite of what they originally established. And now that the rift between these two old friends and colleagues has been laid bare, the only person who can do anything about it is the person who has practically made a religion of keeping his head down. Mueller has a narrowing path along which he might hope to salvage his own words and his own work from the attorney general, who seems to have taken custody of Muellerâ€™s â€œbabyâ€ and then unabashedly attempted to tell us all that the baby was actually an accent lamp all along. Nobody has been more voluble than I have about Muellerâ€™s right and inclination to quietly do the work, then step aside . But if he doesnâ€™t step into the limelight to say out loud what he has written, and proved, and corroborated, and supported (with evidence Barr seems never to even have inspected ), his entire effort will only serve as confirmation that those of us who still believe in systems and investigations and truth are all a bunch of chumps. I donâ€™t envy Robert Mueller. As the one and only character in this endless gothic saga who has managed to remain untarnished by the presidentâ€™s highly contagious lack of principle, I take no pleasure in arguing that he will now have to engage. His silence and doggedness should have spoken louder than words. But in the hands of someone as bent on politicizing his efforts as William Barr, his silence and doggedness have now been weaponized against him. The special counsel cannot just live amid the heroic metaphors anymore. Like Boo Radley, Mueller needs to come out. Support our journalism

column1: William Barrâ€™s Justice Department Just Filed the Most Nakedly Political Brief in the Agencyâ€™s History
column8:
Barr Rigged Trumpâ€™s Acquittal On Wednesday afternoon, after Attorney General William Barr finished his truculent and mendacious testimony before the Senate, the Department of Justice filed perhaps the most embarrassing, illogical, and nakedly political brief in the history of the agency. With Barrâ€™s assent, the DOJ argued that the entire Affordable Care Act is unconstitutional because Congress zeroed out the individual mandateâ€™s penalty in 2017. The timing couldnâ€™t be worse. After obliterating his own credibility at the Senate hearing, Barr scorched the Justice Departmentâ€™s legitimacy, deploying fatuous pseudo-legal arguments to further the Trump administrationâ€™s partisan goals. The DOJ will not soon recover from Wednesdayâ€™s body blow. Texas v. United States , the latest assault on the ACA, is built upon a series of sophistries. The case was brought by a coalition of conservative states, led by Texas, which recruited two consultants to serve as plaintiffs. They assert that when Congress reduced the ACAâ€™s penalty to zero dollars, it inadvertently destroyed the whole lawâ€”the tax credits, the exchanges, protections for preexisting conditions, Medicaid expansion, everything. According to Texasâ€™ theory, the Supreme Court only upheld the ACA because it interpreted the penalty as a tax. But, they claim, a tax that collects zero dollars is not a true tax. So the individual mandate can no longer be viewed as a tax, rendering it unconstitutional. And because Congress never intended the ACA to function without the individual mandate, the rest of the law must be struck down too. This leap in logic makes no sense. It is true that taxes typically collect revenue, so perhaps the mandate cannot fairly be called a tax anymore. It could even be true that the zeroed-out penalty is now unconstitutional. But that does not matter , because ifthe penalty is illegal, it should be severed from the rest of the law. As the Supreme Court recently explained , when one provision of a statute is invalidated, courts should preserve the remainder of the law unless it is â€œevidentâ€ that Congress â€œwould not have enacted those provisions â€¦ independently.â€ In other words, courts that strike down part of a law should not eviscerate the rest of it without evidence that Congress wouldâ€™ve wanted that extreme result. Here, congressional intent is about as clear as it can get. In 2017, Congress declined to repeal the entire ACA but chose to zero out the individual mandateâ€™s penalty in the tax bill . By doing so, it declared its belief that the law could function without an operative penalty, a lawful exercise of its legislative powers. But Texas claimed that by amending the ACA, Congress inadvertently demolished it, because the law cannot function without a penaltyâ€”even though Congress decided that it could. Thus, according to the plaintiffs, courts should simply sweep aside this legislative intent and invalidate the law top to bottom. Congressional intent is about as clear as it can get. In an opinion panned by liberals and conservatives alike, U.S. District Judge Reed Oâ€™Connor embraced this theory late last year and ruled that the entire ACA is unconstitutional. This view was too militant even for Attorney General Jeff Sessionsâ€™ Justice Department, which opted for a compromise position: It alleged that the mandate was unconstitutional but that only a few other provisions must fall with it. This half-measure was still a big deal, because the DOJ urged the courts to kill a centerpiece of the law: its bar on discrimination against people with preexisting conditions. And the DOJâ€™s brief at the time reflected, as University of Michigan law professor Nicholas Bagley put it , â€œenormous contempt for the rule of law.â€ It was, as other scholars noted , â€œexcruciatingly stupid.â€ But at least the DOJ did not go whole hog, adopting Texasâ€™ radical position that courts should reject Congressâ€™ authority to amend its own law. Until now. After Barr took control of the DOJ, the agency changed its position and has now told the 5 th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals that Texas is rightâ€”the full ACA is now unconstitutional. With a straight face, the Justice Department argues that, by reducing the mandate to zero dollars, Congress gave Americans a â€œlegal commandâ€ to buy health insurance. The Supreme Court has said that such a direct command would be unconstitutional because the mandate could only be justified as a tax. Moreover, the justices who discussed severability said that the ACA cannot function without the mandate. In sum, the DOJ wrote, the mandate is now illegal, it cannot be severed, and so the whole law is unconstitutional. Where to begin with this lunacy? Start with the DOJâ€™s framing of the mandate as it stands now. As a factual matter, the ACA currently gives Americans a choice between buying health insurance and paying nothing. Thereâ€™s no real dispute here; if you forgo insurance, you will suffer no legal consequences. Yet the DOJ interprets the mandate as a â€œcommandâ€ that gives Americans â€œno choiceâ€ but to purchase insurance. And its brief insists that Congress created this command in its 2017 tax billâ€”even though legislators surely knew that the Supreme Court already ruled that such a command would be unconstitutional in 2012â€™s NFIB v. Sebelius . It requires willing suspension of disbelief to surmise that by giving Americans a choice not to buy insurance by zeroing out the mandate, Congress actually gave them a â€œcommandâ€ to insure themselves. And it taxes credulity to believe that Congress would create this â€œcommandâ€ after the Supreme Court stated that such a rule would be unconstitutional. But imagine for a moment that the DOJ is rightâ€”that the Republican-led Congress of 2017 didnâ€™t actually relieveAmericans of their duty to buy health insurance but forcedthem to do so (without any enforcement mechanism). If the courts must strike down this new â€œlegal command,â€ why should the remainder of the law fall with it? After all, Congress obviously thought the ACA could function without a mandate that raises revenue. To square this circle, the DOJ repeatedly cites the dissent in NFIB , which proclaimed that the mandate could not be severed from the remainder of the law. The Justice Department seems to think that the view of four dissenting justices (in a 2012 case) can override the view of Congress (in 2017 legislation). It appears to have forgotten that a dissent is not law. The zaniest portion of Wednesdayâ€™s brief, however, has to be its effort to salvage the few provisions of the ACA that the current administration likes. It does so by selectively raising the problem of standing. Now, in reality, the individual plaintiffs in this caseâ€”two consultants who donâ€™t want to buy health insuranceâ€”shouldnâ€™t have standing to sue at all. That requires an injury, and these plaintiffs have none , because they pay no penalty for forgoing insurance. The DOJ casts this problem aside by asserting that they are injured by the â€œlegal commandâ€ to insure themselves. And its brief argues that the plaintiffs have standing â€œto challenge the numerous provisions of the ACA that work together to causeâ€ this injury. But in a puzzling paragraph, the DOJ adds that the plaintiffs do not have standing to challenge several provisions of the ACA that criminalize health care fraud. Why? The real answer is that the Justice Department is already prosecuting people under these provisions, and those prosecutions would be thwarted if the full law were struck down. But the DOJ avows that while the plaintiffs have standing to challenge almost the entire ACA, they canâ€™t challenge these provisions because they do not â€œactually injure the individual plaintiffs.â€ Oh, really? So the rule that insurers not discriminate against people with preexisting conditions, and the tax credits for lower-income Americans, and the expansion of Medicaid in states other than Texas â€”all these provisions â€œactually injureâ€ the plaintiffs? But prohibitions on fraud somehow do not? The DOJ makes no effort to defend this evanescent distinction, because it is indefensible. Barr reportedly opposed adopting this preposterous position but caved to President Donald Trumpâ€™s demands. He deserves no credit for his feeble resistance. Barr owns this brief , and it will live on as a testament to his craven lawlessness long after the Supreme Court rejects its casuistry. The Justice Departmentâ€™s reputation will take years to recover from this nadir, if it ever does. Barr marched his agency to the brink of illegitimacy. Support our journalism

column1: Xavi Made Modern Soccer. Did the Game Leave Him Behind?
column8: Rockets-Warriors Was All About One Specific Type of Foul In 1814, the French mathematician Pierre-Simon Laplace posited a hypothetical intelligence that, given the location of every atom in the universe and the forces acting upon them, would be able to calculate the future with the same clarity with which it observed the past. This concept, which would come to be known as Laplaceâ€™s demon , would know all the causes and thus be able to see all the effects. The entire universe, from its beginning to its end, would be contained within its mind. Xavi, soccerâ€™s own Laplaceâ€™s demon, announced Thursday that he would retire at the end of this season after 17 years at Barcelona and four lucrative swan-song seasons at the Qatari club Al-Sadd. No one in the history of the sport has ever controlled games like the diminutive Spaniard did; no one has ever been as good at the simple task of receiving the ball and knowing immediately where it needs to go next. He played as though he could see the future, as though the only input required for him to map out the rest of the game was the kickoff. Xavi sat at the literal center of two of this centuryâ€™s most dominant teams, and he, more than anyoneâ€”and in this case, â€œanyoneâ€ includes all-timers Thierry Henry, Gerard PiquÃ©, and even Lionel Messiâ€”dictated how Barcelona and Spain played: retaining possession through short passing in close quarters, bending and eventually exhausting defenses with their intricate movement. Xavi found little pockets of space and weaponized them. Between 2008 and 2012, he won two Champions League trophies, three Spanish La Liga titles, two European Championships, and one World Cup, or just about everything it was possible for him to win. Yet because his game appeared so simple, because he did the things everyone is supposed to do only better, it took years for him to get the acclaim he deserved. Even after he was named the best player of the 2008 European Championship, halfway through a year spent masterminding the most dominant club season in recent history with Pep Guardiolaâ€™s first Barcelona team, the Daily Mail published a headline over a picture of the five nominees for the FIFA World Player of the Year Award that read â€œ The Best Players in the World (and Xavi) .â€ He might still be undervalued, despite all those trophies. The soccer magazine FourFourTwo named him the 50 th best player of all time in 2017, which one day is going to seem nearly as ridiculous as â€œ(and Xavi).â€ His presence on the field wasnâ€™t additive but multiplicative. Perhaps the difficulty of appraisal stems from the fact that he was so different from the midfield idols he supplanted: inexhaustible battlers like Roy Keane and Patrick Vieira, polished playmakers like KakÃ¡ and Pavel Nedved. Xavi was the stylistic opposite of the 2006 World Cupâ€™s best player, Zinedine Zidane. Even at 34, Zidane dominated games, arresting the eye like a bolt of lightning. You were always conscious of him, always waiting for his next audacious display, up to and including the career-ending head-butt in that World Cupâ€™s final. Xavi never played that way. He was a conduit, shepherding the game but not overwhelming it. He was not the kind of player you were always aware of; indeed, he moved about the pitch so much youâ€™d be hard-pressed to keep constant tabs on him. Instead, youâ€™d notice his contributionâ€”a sudden, surprising one-touch pass to split two different layers of defendersâ€”then go back via replay or rewind and discover that of course it was him. Trying to spot Xaviâ€™s next pass before he played it was a good way to prove how little you knew about the game. He saw his options faster than you could even with your advantage of the wide shot. His presence on the field wasnâ€™t additive but multiplicative. His entire game fit into one of our most-hallowed sporting clichÃ©s: He made his teammates better. On a squad of zeroes, the effect might be small; it wasnâ€™t until this season that Al-Sadd won the Qatar Stars League with him, and heâ€™s been hurt for much of the year anyway. But for Spain and Barcelona, his contribution was so immense it defined an era of the sport. Following Spainâ€™s World Cup triumph in 2010, the teamâ€™s style, known as tiki-taka, appeared poised to sweep the world. Brendan Rodgers rode a couple of seasons of overachieving possession-based soccer at Swansea to the top job at Liverpool. JÃ¼rgen Klinsmannâ€™s hire in 2011 as the U.S. menâ€™s national team coach hinged on his promises to bring more possession play: â€œIf you play Brazil or Argentina, you might play differently than maybe a country in CONCACAF, but it is a starting point if you say we want to start to keep possession, we want to start to dictate the pace of the game, we want to challenge our players to improve technically in order to keep the ball.â€ Results were mixed, we might charitably say. The chasm between original and imitators was never bridged. Teams such as Jose Mourinhoâ€™s Inter Milan had sporadic success designing labyrinthine bunkers for Xavi and AndrÃ©s Iniesta to navigate during that 2008â€“12 run, but it was the development of more sophisticated pressing and counterpressing strategies that ultimately supplanted tiki-taka as the tactic du jour, largely because those schemes were the first to reliably beat it. The longest section of the tiki-taka Wikipedia page is about the strategies other teams developed to beat Spain and Barcelona , starting with the U.S. national teamâ€™s win over the Spanish in the 2009 Confederations Cup semifinal, Spainâ€™s first defeat in 36 matches. Surprisingly, the list doesnâ€™t include simply waiting them out. Not to take away from the achievement of Diego Simeoneâ€™s title-winning AtlÃ©tico Madrid in 2014, but itâ€™s no coincidence the all-consuming whirlwind unleashed by Xaviâ€™s teams subsided just as age caught up to him. Instead of a stylistic revolution, tiki-taka turned out to be a complex exoskeleton constructed around his singular genius. Remove its pilot, or slow him down a crucial step or two, and what you were left with was a clunky and easily disrupted machine like the one eliminated before the knockout round of the 2014 World Cup. Barcelona adapted its tactics to play faster and has won four of the last five La Liga titles. Spain has clung harder to the style and, after a brilliant qualifying campaign, finally passed itself to death against the hosts during the 2018 World Cup in Russia. Even Guardiolaâ€™s Manchester City doesnâ€™t attempt what his Barcelona did with Xavi at the helm. The next step for Xavi, the obvious step almost since he turned professional, is coaching. He may start in Qatar, perhaps with Al-Sadd, perhaps eventually even taking over the countryâ€™s national side ahead of the 2022 World Cup. There may be other stops along the way, but the final destination feels inevitable: Barcelona. No one is more ingrained in the Barcelona way. Even in Qatar, he remained the clubâ€™s moral philosopher and an easy source for quotes on a range of Barcelona-adjacent subjects, from questioning the current status of its famed youth academy to piling slight after slight on Neymar for daring to leave for Paris Saint-Germain. The one constant to it all is a strict interpretation of what it means to play the Barcelona way. As he put it in his retirement announcement: â€œI love seeing the teams take the initiative on the field, play attacking football and return to the essence of what we all loved since our childhood days: football possession.â€ If, or when, he does get the Barcelona job, that dogma may be tested. Will he learn to be flexible? Or does he have a solution to the problem that has stymied the world since his peak: How do you play like Xavi without Xavi?

column1: Report: FBI Sent Undercover Agent to Meet With Papadopoulos During 2016 Campaign
column8:
William Barr Is a Different Kind of Trump Surrogate In 2016, the FBI sent a trusted investigator posing as an academicâ€™s assistant to ask Donald Trump aide George Papadopoulos about the Trump campaignâ€™s links to Russia, the New York Times reported Thursday. The news of such a proactive step by the agency is likely to cause some Trump supporters to accuse the FBI of â€œspyingâ€ on Trump and his campaign in an effort to damage his chances of winning, as Trump himself has insisted in the past. But the effort can also be interpreted as a signal of how concerned the FBI was at the time about potential Russian inference in the election. The FBI became alarmed about that possibility in the summer of 2016 after Papadopoulos told an Australian diplomat that the Russians had offered to help the Trump campaign by releasing the emails hacked from the Hillary Clinton campaign and the Democratic National Committee. The Australian government alerted American officials once Wikileaks published that trove of hacked emails, and the FBI opened its Russia investigation in July 2016. According to the Times, the FBI decided to look into whether Papadopoulos had Russian contacts. During the investigation, the agency decided to also look into Paul Manafort, Michael Flynn, and Carter Page. The FBI then had Cambridge professor Stefan A. Halper, reportedly a longtime informant, reach out to Papadopoulos to set up a meeting in London to discuss a Mediterranean natural gas project. The FBI also sent along a trained agent, who had given her name as Azra Turk, to pose as Halperâ€™s assistant. The two were meant to quiz Papadopoulos about any connection between the campaign and Russia, and Turk also met with Papadopoulos separately for drinks. Papadopoulos wrote in his book that when he met Turk in London in September, she began to immediately press him about the campaignâ€™s connection to Russia. (British intelligence officials were also notified about the operation, according to the Times, but itâ€™s unclear if they were at all involved.). He wrote that he met with both Turk and Halper the next day, and in a follow-up drink with Halper, the professor began immediately quizzing him about the hacked emails and Russia. Turk and Halper did not learn anything of significance from the effort, but Halper, a well-connected academic, continued his work with the FBI. He met repeatedly with Page and gradually became more closely connected to the Trump world. The FBI has said the agency carefully considered the seriousness of monitoring an active presidential campaign, according to the Times, and it was careful that word of the investigation should not reach the public. Michael Horowitz, the Justice Department inspector general, is investigating the FBIâ€™s activities, including those involving Halper, before the 2016 election. Attorney General William Barr has said the results of that investigation could be completed in the next couple months. Support our journalism

column1: My cats only sleep outside, and Iâ€™m worried: pet advice from Beast Mode.
column8: My Momâ€™s Dog Despairs Each Morning I Canâ€™t Walk Her. Should I Stop Doing It on Weekends? Two kittens bumbled into our backyard and our lives last summer, and what started out as my little project to make sure they got some food and got neuteredâ€”through our SPCAâ€™s trap-and-release programâ€”turned into something bigger. Now my husband and I have two cats. Theyâ€™re socializing well and they come inside a lot, even to sit on the couch and snuggle with us. Theyâ€™ve been to the vet and had all their shots and get monthly flea treatments. For now, they sleep in a little heated tent on our deck, which they took to immediately and treat as their home base. But I would like to transition them to being indoors more. Weâ€™re aiming to at least bring them inside at night to keep them safer and so they wonâ€™t have to deal with temperature extremes. Do you have any tips on making this transition a smooth one? Weâ€™re considering installing a cat flap to see if that makes them more comfortable. Would moving their tent inside as part of their move be a good idea? â€”Cats Under a Cold Tin Roof Dear Cats Under a Cold Tin Roof, Welcoming strange beings into your life is a scary proposition, so allow me to commend these cats for their bravery. Humans can be unpredictable and messy, but theyâ€™ve found two adoptees who possess great demeanors and a willingness to learn. Itâ€™s a perfect match. You and your husband deserve praise as well. The strays may have adopted you, but youâ€™ve accepted the responsibility of keeping them healthy and safe with compassion and patience. By the sound of it, youâ€™ve done a swell job so far. Iâ€™m sure the cats feel the same, even if theyâ€™re too busy glamping in their heated tent to tell you so. Be prepared to deal with two cranky and put-upon cats at first. If you feel totally ready to keep the cats under your roof at night, then, by all means, go for it. â€œItâ€™s certainly safer for the cats to be indoors at night,â€ certified animal behaviorist Mikel Delgado says . â€œThereâ€™s more risk of injury and other wildlife [encounters] during the dark hours.â€ To habituate them to being inside, Delgado says itâ€™s all about creating a welcoming environment that they will enjoyâ€”especially since there will be more than one cat in the home. â€œMake sure there are enough resources for the cats to use,â€ she tells me. â€œThat means multiple feeding dishes, multiple litter boxes, vertical space, things that they can climb, places to sleep.â€ The tent youâ€™ve pitched is a clear example of the kindness youâ€™ve shown to these cats, but you donâ€™t have to restructure some of your own indoor living space to accommodate this edifice. If it creates needless clutter, feel free to keep it on the deck. The cats will deal. As with the tent, the cat flap isnâ€™t necessary to facilitate a smooth transition. â€œIâ€™m more of a cold-turkey person. Once they get used to the cat flap, great, but then that will have to change,â€ Delgado says. â€œIf they truly want the cats indoors at night, then they should just rip the Band-Aid off.â€ In the long run, it will be less of a hassle than pitching a tent inside or punching a hole in your door. Speaking of hassles, be prepared to deal with two cranky and put-upon cats at first. â€œTheyâ€™re going to protest for a few days because of the change of routine, but that wonâ€™t mean they wonâ€™t adjust,â€ Delgado says. It is key that you ignore this behavior, because they will interpret any responseâ€”even if itâ€™s just telling them to shut upâ€”as encouragement to meow and whine even more. â€œCats are very good at manipulating humans,â€ Delgado says. And how. This is a big move, both for you and the cats, so now is the time to consider everything that this change in accommodations will entail. Because once you decide to upend their nighttime routine, itâ€™s up to you to stay the course. â€œIf these people have decided that this is the safest option for these cats,â€ Delgado says, â€œthen they should just jump in and do it.â€ The move may be difficult initially, but if you get them on a routine and make them feel comfortable in their environment, then the cats should warm up to the new digs. They may stay outside all day, but theyâ€™ll be happy to call your house their home at night. They adopted you for a reason, after all.

column1: That Movie About Charlize Theron Falling for a Schlubby Seth Rogen Is Actually Pretty Feminist
column8:
Under the Silver Lake Is a Total Mess and Totally Worth It Like many rom-com heroines, Long Shot â€™s Charlotte Field (Charlize Theron) has an aspirational job, a glitzy wardrobe that makes zero sense for her salary, and an unwitting need for the right guy to come along, loosen her up, and inject some fun into her life. Unlike many rom-com heroines, Charlotte curses, has sex, occasionally wears dowdy pantsuits, and, most notably, throws even more of herself into her career at the end of the movie, to the absolute delight of her male partner, Fred (Seth Rogen). In Long Shot â€™s worldâ€”as in oursâ€”public-facing women are relentlessly scrutinized, and powerful ones are generally considered too intimidating to date. The filmâ€™s irresistible fantasyâ€”and hopefully, increasingly, our realityâ€”is that there are men who are perfectly content supporting their high-powered wives, just as women have been doing for their husbands for most of recorded history. Helmed by Jonathan Levine, who also directed Rogen in 50/50 and The Night Before , and based on a screenplay by Dan Sterling ( The Interview )and Liz Hannah ( The Post ), Long Shot fits neatly in the actorâ€™s wheelhouse in most ways. It features a solid joke just about every minuteâ€”many of them about masturbation, pop culture, and Rogenâ€™s characterâ€™s Jewishness. It also includes a getting-high sequence, unabashedly liberal politics, and more than a twinge of self-pity about Rogenâ€™s honestly-pretty-good looks (more on this later). But Long Shot feels like something new, tooâ€”a brogressive rom-com that mixes inconvenient boners and aerodynamic cum with extensive observations about sexism and a rare romanticization of the male helpmate. The movie doesnâ€™t get all its gender dynamics right, and an out-of-nowhere call for bipartisan cooperation feels like a ham-fisted insertion by a nervous studio exec. But all the way up to its own version of a happy ending, itâ€™s a fresh, timely spin on the rom-com formula, the next step forward after the feminist strides in Rogenâ€™s Neighbors movies and a possible new path for dude comedies that are no longer content to pretend that women donâ€™t have our own stuff going on. Before it refers to the disparity in status and attractiveness between Charlotte and Fred, the â€œlong shotâ€ of the title describes the presidential prospects of Charlotte, the youngest secretary of state ever and a frequent target of ogling by conservative pundits. Charlotte serves a popular, numpty president (Bob Odenkirk) who became commander-in-chief by playing one on TV (his favorite line: â€œIâ€™m not nuking a tsunami!â€), and who has to be tricked into thinking her ideas are his to implement them. When her boss decides heâ€™d rather pursue a movie career than seek reelection, Charlotte decides to throw her hat into the ringâ€”and after a series of convolutions, hires as one of her speechwriters the unemployed firebrand journalist Fred, who she used to babysit 25 years ago. Charlotte and her team travel to nearly two dozen countries together as she attempts to sell an environmental deal that will make her a competitive candidate, and in such close-quartered conditions, the politico and the writer fall for each otherâ€™s idealism and accomplishments, even as they disagree on whether itâ€™s OK to compromise to effect change. (Anyone still smarting from the intra-Democratic battles of 2016 should find some salve in this romance between Hot Hillary and a Bernie bro.) But when Charlotte wins the sitting presidentâ€™s endorsement, her protective aide (June Diane Raphael) warns that the public wonâ€™t accept a model-esque woman with a schlub like Fred. Apparently the voters in this universe have never seen most movies, television shows, lots and lots of real-life couplesâ€”or simply donâ€™t register that â€œmixed-attractivenessâ€ relationships arenâ€™t all that rare. Long Shot feels like something newâ€”a brogressive rom-com. Rogen is as funny as heâ€™s ever been, but itâ€™s Theron whoâ€™s the standout. She makes the absurdities of Charlotteâ€™s life, like being unable to eat skewered foods in public or â€œmicro-nappingâ€ while standing with her eyes open, seem not only believable, but human. The movie has plenty of compassion for the thousand and one constraints Charlotte has to keep in mind at all times (donâ€™t be â€œangry,â€ but donâ€™t be â€œweakâ€), but what hits hardest are the moments when we see her breezily commanding leadership in action. In front of the cameras, sheâ€™s buttoned-up but learning how to open up (mostly through the jokes and autobiographical details Fred peppers into her speeches). But when she needs to get things done behind the scenes, she displays a surgical decisiveness, a treasure trove of wonky knowledge, and a no-bullshit matter-of-factness thatâ€™s impossible not to get a girl crush on. Itâ€™s the kind of nonpathologized portrayal of a woman taking charge that knocks you off your seat because you hadnâ€™t realized how much you were missing it. I do wish weâ€™d gotten to see Charlotte actually making deals, thoughâ€” Long Shot would have you believe that being secretary of state is just jet-setting around the world, attending fancy parties, and tangoing with the prime minister of Canada (Alexander Skarsgard, in a hilarious sendup of his beefcake image). The eleventh hour in a rom-com tends to be my least favorite, when the destined couple mope around for a few minutes before reuniting for the final time. Rogen is clearly responding to one particular strain of the backlash against Knocked Up that pointed to the attractiveness gap between him and co-star Katherine Heiglâ€”a criticism meant to draw attention to the ostensible sexism of the movie as well as of the industry at large . column1: William Barr Is a Different Kind of Trump Surrogate
column8:
How Are We Supposed to Understand Brett Kavanaugh Now? Given his tendency to employ the colorful over the competent, itâ€™s slightly surprising that Donald Trumpâ€™s taste in attorneys general has bypassed loudmouths like Rudy Giuliani in favor of small, precise men. Both Jeff Sessions and William Barr are notable for their unintimidating demeanor and for the skill with which they couch extreme ideology in the garb of conventional, calm lawyering. Perhaps this is the kind of person the president believes will accept his documented efforts to dictate terms to the Department of Justice. Or maybe his tendency to view the attorney general as his own personal lawyer, rather than Americaâ€™s top law enforcement officer, led him to choose a type he thought he could dominate. Itâ€™s no secret that Trump considered Sessionsâ€™ decision to recuse himself from the Mueller probeâ€”ethically, the bare minimumâ€”a personal betrayal. (Trump felt the attorney general should have protected him, and Sessionsâ€™ failure to do so is one reason heâ€™s no longer in the role.) In Barr, Trump has found an attorney general with hoary Republican bona fides who accepts Trumpâ€™s view and has developed a theory according to which Trumpâ€™s feelings not only matter more than the law, but should dictate it. Barrâ€™s ideology is a fit, and soâ€”for a TV president who prizes style over substanceâ€”is his stagecraft. Barr has developed a theory according to which Trumpâ€™s feelings not only matter more than the law, but should dictate it. Though stolid and undramatic, William Barr has proven himself an eager finger-pointer (singling out Rod Rosenstein, Robert Mueller, the media, and Trumpâ€™s opponents for particular blame) and an able advocate for the agitated president. Thatâ€™s not his role, of courseâ€”or it shouldnâ€™t beâ€”but Barr keeps slipping into outright advocacy for the man he was theoretically supposed to consider indicting. Appearing before the Senate Judiciary Committee on Wednesday to answer questions about the Mueller report, Barr made his allegiances obvious. Asked about Trumpâ€™s remarks excoriating people who â€œflipâ€ on the wrongdoers above them, Barr took the remarkable step of ventriloquizing the presidentâ€™s defense. â€œI think what the presidentâ€™s lawyers would say,â€ he said (as if he werenâ€™t acting as one), â€œis that the presidentâ€™s statements about flipping are quite clear and express and uniformly the same, which is by â€˜flipping,â€™ he meant succumbing to pressure on unrelated cases to lie and compose in order to get lenient treatment.â€ (Carried away by this role-playing, Barr would eventually go on to ventriloquize not only Trumpâ€™s lawyers, but Trump himself.) Barr isnâ€™t only there to translate Trumpâ€™s mafia-speak into legitimate legalese. The attorney general, who has a long history of doing all he can to maximize executive power, appears to be on a mission to make presidents even more legally untouchable than they already are. His strategy isnâ€™t confrontational; itâ€™s staid in ways that camouflage the extraordinary deference heâ€™s showing to the presidentâ€™s moods. Barr has already argued that making a determination of corrupt intent requires a deep and sympathetic study of the presidentâ€™s grievances. He accordingly channels the presidentâ€™s sulks just as he explains his slang: Barr explained Trump was â€œfrustrated and angeredâ€ by public concern that he might have done questionable things against the national interestâ€”like invite the Russians to hack into Hillary Clintonâ€™s emails , hire a compromised foreign agent as national security adviser , or give sensitive Israeli intelligence to the Russians. Barrâ€™s calculus accords the presidentâ€™s frustration so much legal weight that Trumpâ€™s â€œwitch huntsâ€ and â€œAngry Democratsâ€ and dangled pardons and attempted firings of the special counsel are, all things considered, more than reasonable. By contrast, he characterizes public alarm over the aforementioned activities as not only unreasonable but evidence of how unfairly the president has been treated . â€œAs he entered into office, and sought to perform his responsibilities as president, federal agents and prosecutors were scrutinizing his conduct before and after taking office, and the conduct of some of his associates,â€ Barr explained while defending the presidentâ€™s outrage in his press conference before releasing the Mueller report. â€œAt the same time, there was relentless speculation in the news media about the presidentâ€™s personal culpability.â€ If Barr extends to the president a therapistâ€™s compassion, he seems to find Mueller, his longtime friend and colleague, both incomprehensible and incorrect. â€œIâ€™m not really sure of his reasoning,â€ Barr said when he was asked whether he agreed with Muellerâ€™s reasons, outlined in his report, for not offering a definite pronouncement on whether prosecution was appropriate. â€œI really could not recapitulate his analysis, which is one of the reasons in my March 24 letter I simply stated the fact that he did not reach a conclusion and didnâ€™t try to put words in his mouth.â€ To sum up: Barr not only refused to publish the summaries Mueller himself wrote for the public, but he also wrote up such a misleading summary that the famously taciturn special counsel formally objected, asking again that his own summaries be released. And then , having substituted his own text for Muellerâ€™s, Barr demurely suggested he hadnâ€™t wanted to put words in Muellerâ€™s mouth. This priggish sleight of hand is Barrâ€™s wheelhouse. He launders impropriety with a functionaryâ€™s demeanor and a spin doctorâ€™s acumen. In Wednesdayâ€™s hearing, Barrâ€™s professional reserve became a kind of smoke screen for repeated swipes at the special counsel. He suggested, for instance, that Mueller should have â€œpulled upâ€ (whatever that means) if he thought he wasnâ€™t in a position to pronounce: â€œI think that if he felt that he shouldnâ€™t go down the path of making a traditional prosecutive decision, he shouldnâ€™t have. That was the time to pull up.â€ This curious statement omits Muellerâ€™s clear explanation that his decision not to charge was not because prosecution wasnâ€™t appropriate, but because it wasnâ€™t up to him to make the next move. The next move, Mueller clearly notes, is up to Congress. Barr disagrees with this. â€œIâ€™m the captain,â€ he said of the report. â€œThis is my baby.â€ Barrâ€™s composure was an inverse function of the legal acrobatics he was attempting. That phrasing was pretty weird, but on the whole, Barrâ€™s conduct was calm, courteous, and slightly condescending. It was professional and meant to reassure. He framed extraordinary claims as if they were simple common sense, peppering his remarks with obviously s and looking for all the world like the put-upon bureaucrat. He would not concede that the presidentâ€™s conduct was concerning or wrong or unbefitting, repeatedly insisting that it was â€œconstitutional.â€ He characterized concerns about Russian efforts to compromise Trumpâ€™s campaign as overblown while noting that the phenomenon of foreign governments targeting Americans is rather commonplace, even generic. Under duress, he admitted that a presidential campaign should call the FBI if thus approached, but seemed unwilling to condemn or even disapprove of Trumpâ€™s campaign for failing to do so. Even Barrâ€™s petty moments were muted. Yes, he called Muellerâ€™s letter â€œsnitty,â€ but spared Mueller the insult by proposing that someone else had written it. (This sly little suggestion does double work, of course: It supports his earlier claim that he didnâ€™t know what Mueller thought. Anyone on his staff might have written that letter!) When Sen. Richard Blumenthal observed that Muellerâ€™s letter was a truly exceptional interventionâ€”â€œan extraordinary act, a career prosecutor rebuking the attorney general of the United States, memorializing it in writing, right? I know of no other instance of that happeningâ€â€”a nettled Barr replied pedantically: â€œWell, I donâ€™t consider Bob at this stage a career prosecutor. Heâ€™s had a career as a prosecutor.â€ This level of self-control, unusual in Trumpâ€™s circles, has advantages. Barrâ€™s composure was an inverse function of the legal acrobatics he was attempting: He posits, for instance, that the investigation was illegitimate because the president wasnâ€™t indicted. It follows that obstruction is impossible! Since Mueller didnâ€™t pronounce on the presidentâ€™s criminality, anything the president did to stop the inquiry was fair (Barr likes the phrase â€œthe exercise of his constitutional dutiesâ€). This is the kind of wackadoodle argument one has to read several times through in order to absorb its astonishing implications; it seems to suggest that law enforcement may only pursue inquiries it knows to be true while ignoring that the pursuit is how we discover truth. This legal theory of time travel is presented as sensible and self-evident. Itâ€™s boring to blame our reality TV president for nudging the government toward reality TV shenanigans, but we work with the gifts we have. Inflammatory theatrics are Trumpâ€™s one proven skillâ€”he likes to say his picks are â€œstraight out of central casting.â€ Heâ€™s not wrong: They have tended to be larger-than-life and unconcerned about things like respectability (Anthony Scaramucci, Steve Bannon, Omarosa). Even Trump acolytes who care about such thingsâ€”like Brett Kavanaugh, or the Lindsey Graham of yoreâ€”have sacrificed their probity to put on the kind of big angry show Trump loves. But in William Barr, Trump has found a new sort of character, to fill a new sort of need. Reality TV is famously scripted to maximize drama. The fights and tantrums tend to work if you squint, even if you know theyâ€™re manufactured. They attract an audience. But depending on what youâ€™re going for, sometimes you donâ€™t want too much attention. If you want a clean way to make the really giant twists seem boring, even routine, what you need is a drama minimizer: someone who can pass off chaos as bureaucracy. Or obstruction as constitutional duty. Or one manâ€™s feelings as American law. For that, Donald Trump has William Barr. Support our journalism
